newsitem.title: USA: Indiana wheat ratings slip, corn planting proceeds.
newsitem.headline: Indiana wheat ratings slip, corn planting proceeds.

text.p: The condition of Indiana's winter wheat crop slipped a bit during the week ended April 20, according to the weekly crop report from Indiana's Agricultural Statistics Service.
The winter wheat crop was rated 57 percent good to excellent, down from last week's good to excellent rating of 66 percent.
The wheat crop was 27 percent jointed, versus last week's pace of 13 percent and the five-year average of 22 percent, the report said.

Indiana farmers also began to plant corn at a more active rate, the report said. Corn planting progress was five percent in the latest week, versus the previous week's rating of one percent and the five-year average of three percent, the report said.
"Corn planting is picking up speed around the state," the report said. "The best progress was made in the northwest quadrant of the state."
Tillage operations also made good progress as farmers continued to apply fertilizer. Much of the acreage is awaiting warmer soil temperatures for seeding, the report said.
For the week ending Friday, 3.5 days were suitable for fieldwork. Topsil moisture was rated 73 percent adequate.
